meanings.definition: Pull or twist out of shape
meanings.sent1: She tried to distort the rubber band by stretching it too far.
meanings.sent2: The artist accidentally distorted the clay sculpture while shaping it.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous puppy managed to distort the perfectly round ball into a lopsided shape.
meanings.sent4: The strong wind began to distort the shape of the flag, making it ripple and twist.
meanings.sent5: The heat caused the plastic ruler to distort, bending it out of its original form.

meanings.definition: Give a misleading or false account or impression of
meanings.sent1: The tabloid newspaper often tries to distort the truth to sell more copies.
meanings.sent2: It is unethical to distort facts in order to win an argument.
meanings.sent3: The magician's mirror distorted his reflection, making him appear shorter than he actually was.
meanings.sent4: The funhouse mirrors distorted the image of the visitors, making them look funny and exaggerated.
meanings.sent5: The old photograph had faded and distorted over time, making it hard to recognize the people in it.

meanings.definition: Alter the form of (an electrical signal or sound wave) by increasing some frequencies more than others.
meanings.sent1: The radio receiver can distort the sound if the frequencies are not balanced correctly.
meanings.sent2: Be careful not to distort the audio signal when adjusting the volume on the amplifier.
meanings.sent3: The faulty speaker began to distort the music, making it sound scratchy and unclear.
meanings.sent4: The old record player would sometimes distort the vinyl records, creating a unique sound effect.
meanings.sent5: The microphone started to distort the singer's voice when the volume was turned up too high.
